text: 1. 'If, without knowing this, one offers an Agnihotra, it would be as if a man were to remove the live coals and pour his libation on dead ashes.

upanishad: The Upanishads, Part 1 (SBE01): Khândogya Upanishad... | Sacred Texts Archive
translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 2. 'But he who offers this Agnihotra with a full knowledge of its true purport, he offers it (i.e. he eats food) 1 in all worlds, in all beings, in all Selfs.

upanishad: The Upanishads, Part 1 (SBE01): Khândogya Upanishad... | Sacred Texts Archive
translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 3. 'As the soft fibres of the Ishîkâ reed, when thrown into the fire, are burnt, thus all his sins are burnt whoever offers this Agnihotra with a full knowledge of its true purport.

upanishad: The Upanishads, Part 1 (SBE01): Khândogya Upanishad... | Sacred Texts Archive
translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 4. 'Even if he gives what is left of his food to a K a n d âla, it would be offered in his (the K a n d âla's) Vai s vânara Self. And so it is said in this S loka:--

upanishad: The Upanishads, Part 1 (SBE01): Khândogya Upanishad... | Sacred Texts Archive
translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 'As hungry children here on earth sit (expectantly) round their mother, so do all beings sit round the Agnihotra, yea, round the Agnihotra.'
